options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live lecture with optional attendance.
Lectures were recorded.
I watched the lectures (sometimes live but mostly recorded)
Lectures were recorded as well.
Office hours.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Complex Analysis: Complex differentiability and holomorphic functions, the Cauchy-Riemann Equations, Complex integration, Cauchy's theorem and integration formula, Morera's theorem, convergence (uniform, absolute, normal) of infinite series, power series expansions of analytic functions, Laurent Series expansion, Calculus of Residues
I gained a basic understanding of complex analysis.

Basics of complex analysis, take any book on the subject and look at what it covers up to the Residue Theorem and its applications, that's essentially what we did. Or in other words, exactly what you'd expect in an intro course.

Holomorphic functions, complex differentiability, Cauchy-Riemann equations, conformal maps, Cauchy's theorem, Cauchy's integral formula, Taylor and Laurent series of complex functions, Residue theory, etc.
Complex numbers, analytic functions, complex integration, power series, laurent series, residue calculus.
Basic concepts in complex analysis: the complex plane, Cauchy-Riemann Equations, complex integration theorems, complex Taylor series, Laurent series, etc.
Holomorphic functions, ML-estimates, Cauchy Integral Formula, Residues.
Complex Analysis by Gamelin.

Several fundamental concepts of complex analysis: complex differentiation and analytic functions, complex integration, Taylor and Laurent series, and residue calculus  chapters 1-7 of "Complex Analysis" by Gamelin.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Weaknesses: Lectures could be disorganized, the professor's handwriting was often quite hard to read/follow (sometimes I couldn't tell if he was stating a claim or if he was asking whether something was true or false), Quizzes and midterms were multiple choice and just a few questions long (so grades get low very quickly and with simple mistakes, didn't really match the type of problems on the HW).

Strengths: Followed the textbook pretty closely, really cool math when you understood it, the group project was fun. Congling's teaching improved over time, and he is very open to feedback.
This course was one of the worst classes I have ever taken. The lectures were very unorganized and hard to follow, and the midterm and final were unnecessarily difficult.

Strengths: Instructor very clearly cared for the class and was very engaging, asking us for feedback throughout the semester. Also, if you've never seen complex analysis before, the subject is honestly quite amazing when you step back and look at some of the results that you have. 

Weaknesses: The lecture style is probably not has proof-heavy as you'd expect. We went through many examples, but a lot of the proofs of theorems were only sketched / mentioned briefly, so I had to fill in those gaps.

I think the book used was excellent. For better or worse, reading the book was the most efficient way of studying for me. I thought that the teaching however was subpar and It'd be interesting to see if other students share the same opinion on that matter.
The course material was interesting. The lectures were disorganized and unclear, however, and I found myself having to learn mostly from the textbook.

Strengths: Course content was very interesting, and I definitely feel like I have a somewhat thorough understanding of these introductory concepts now.

Weaknesses: The classes were a bit disorganized, and sometimes lectures were difficult to follow. The multiple choice quizzes and midterm also didn't feel very helpful at all.
The professor could've made the learning process a lot easier. Sometimes his notes would be hard to read or we couldn't understand him properly.

Strengths: followed a great text closely, reasonable hws, good professor. very helpful office hours.
Weakness: virtual learning makes learning math difficult.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Writing the slides more clearly would have really helped (Maybe typing major claims and then writing to fill in the details?)
Course was fine for virtual engagement; we occasionally had some breakout rooms to discuss problems.
The lectures should definitely be more organized and try to be more clear.
Office hours were very helpful. It was hard to engage in virtual classes, although the professor made a conscious effort to encourage collaboration in group exercises in class.
Allowing students to watch recorded lectures in place of live class. Posting handwritten lecture notes. (Though the handwriting could be better).

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: The professor was accommodating to student requests and often based his decisions off of the class's feedback which is nice.

Unless you knew you specifically wanted to learn complex analysis, I wouldn't recommend this course. Even so, be prepared to do a lot of self-study since the lectures aren't very clear (albeit, that could be in part due to the online format). The math is very cool, but I'm not sure it's worth the frustrations I would sometimes feel. Quizzes and midterms were multiple choice and just a few questions long (so grades get low very quickly and with simple mistakes, didn't really match the type of problems on the HW), and the take-home final was awful (interesting problems, but took a very long time).
If Prof. Qiu is teaching, I would definitely not recommend this course. You will learn very little, and the exams will be extremely difficult.

It was the professor's first time teaching here, so some of the reviews might reflect that, and I would say to take that with a grain of salt. The teaching was rougher at the beginning of the semester but certainly improved towards the end to the point where I thought I was learning the material clearly. Anyways, if you're a math major you have to take this class, so just do it. In the worst case you'll learn from the textbook.

It's tricky. If someone else is teaching it, it's probably worth a shot. Personally, I didn't get much from the lectures and was forced to reading the book as a primary source of information. If you're a math major, you probably have to take this but if you're a physics major just stay away from this course.

I would not recommend this course to another person as I felt I honestly learned mostly from the textbook. The course material was very interesting, but a lot of the course's grading was based around students' ability to catch the tricks Professor Qiu set up.
Yes, although a bit hesitantly. Be prepared to do a decent bit of independent reading to supplement the lectures.
Maybe if the professor changes, or if Congling improves his material.
Yes, this is an essential course for mathematics and physics majors.
Yes.
